item.title: Hilton Pet Policy 2025: Fees, Weight Limits & What to Know Before You Book
item.description:
Planning a Hilton stay with your dog? Good news: every Hilton brand in the U.S. accepts pets. But the details — fees, weight limits, and which properties are best for dogs — vary more than you might expect.

Here’s everything you need to know about Hilton’s pet policy in 2025.

Disclosure: This post contains affiliate links. If you apply for a card through my links, I may earn a commission at no extra cost to you. See my full disclosure for details.

Jump to:

  • The Short Answer
  • Pet Fees by Brand
  • Weight Limits
  • Most Dog-Friendly Brands
  • Booking Tips
  • How to Stay Free

The Short Answer

Does Hilton allow pets? Yes — all Hilton brands in the U.S. accept dogs.

How much is the pet fee? Typically $50–$95 per stay (not per night), but varies by brand and location.

Is there a weight limit? Usually 75 lbs, but some properties cap at 50 lbs. Always call ahead.

Breed restrictions? No official breed restrictions at the corporate level, though individual properties may have their own policies.

Hilton Pet Fees by Brand

Pet fees vary by brand and location. Here’s what to expect:

Brand Typical Pet Fee Notes
Hampton Inn $50–$75/stay Budget-friendly, consistent policies
Hilton Garden Inn $50–$75/stay Good for business travel with dogs
Home2 Suites $50–$75/stay Extended stay, kitchen in room
Homewood Suites $75–$100/stay Suite-style, great for longer trips
Tru by Hilton $50–$75/stay Budget option, newer properties
DoubleTree $50–$75/stay Varies widely by location
Embassy Suites $75–$95/stay All suites, separate living area
Hilton Hotels & Resorts $75–$95/stay Full-service properties
Canopy by Hilton $50–$75/stay Boutique brand, very pet-friendly
Curio Collection Varies Boutique, check specific property
Tapestry Collection Varies Boutique, check specific property
Conrad Hotels $100+/stay Luxury brand, higher fees
Waldorf Astoria $100+/stay Luxury brand, higher fees

Important: These are typical ranges. Always confirm the exact fee when booking — some high-demand locations charge more.

Weight Limits by Brand

Most Hilton brands cap pets at 75 lbs, but this varies by property:

Brand Typical Weight Limit
Hampton Inn 75 lbs
Hilton Garden Inn 75 lbs
Home2 Suites 75 lbs
Homewood Suites 75 lbs
Tru by Hilton 75 lbs
DoubleTree 50–75 lbs (varies)
Embassy Suites 75 lbs
Hilton Hotels 50–75 lbs (varies)
Canopy by Hilton 50–75 lbs
Curio Collection Varies by property
Tapestry Collection Varies by property
Conrad Hotels Varies by property
Waldorf Astoria Varies by property

If your dog is over 75 lbs: Call the property directly before booking. Some locations are flexible, especially for well-behaved dogs. Others are strict. Don’t risk showing up and getting turned away.

Have a large dog? Check out Kimpton hotels — they have NO weight limits and NO pet fees.

Most Dog-Friendly Hilton Brands

If you’re specifically looking for the best Hilton experience with your dog, these brands consistently deliver:

Home2 Suites ⭐ Best Overall

  • Every room has a kitchen (store dog food, prep meals)
  • Spacious layouts with separate areas
  • Usually ground-floor rooms available
  • Consistent 75 lb weight limit
  • Often near outdoor spaces

Homewood Suites ⭐ Best for Extended Stays

  • Full kitchens in every suite
  • Separate living and sleeping areas
  • Evening social hours (free food!)
  • Great for longer road trips

Embassy Suites ⭐ Best for Space

  • Every room is a suite with separate living room
  • Made-to-order breakfast included
  • Evening reception with drinks and snacks
  • More room for your dog to spread out

Canopy by Hilton ⭐ Most Pet-Friendly Vibe

  • Boutique brand with local character
  • Staff genuinely welcoming to dogs
  • Often in walkable neighborhoods
  • Sometimes have treats at check-in

Tips for Booking Hilton with Your Dog

1. Always Call the Property

Online booking shows “pet-friendly,” but doesn’t tell you the weight limit or fee. A 2-minute call confirms:

  • Exact pet fee
  • Weight limit at that location
  • Any breed restrictions
  • Pet relief areas on property

2. Request a Ground Floor Room

Ask for a room near an exit for easy potty breaks. First-floor rooms near a side door are ideal — you can slip out for late-night walks without trekking through the lobby.

3. Add a Note to Your Reservation

When booking online, add a note that you’re traveling with a dog. Include the breed and weight. This flags your reservation so the front desk is prepared.

4. Bring Documentation

Keep your dog’s vaccination records handy. Some properties ask for proof of rabies vaccination at check-in.

5. Know the Rules

Most Hilton properties require:

  • Dogs must be on leash in public areas
  • Dogs cannot be left unattended in rooms (or must be crated)
  • You’re responsible for any damage
  • No dogs in pool, fitness center, or restaurant areas

How to Book Hilton Free with Points

Pet fees are unavoidable, but the room itself can be free. I use Hilton credit cards to earn points on everyday spending, then book award nights at pet-friendly properties.

The math: A typical Hilton stay costs 30,000–60,000 points per night. The Hilton Surpass card has a 155,000-point sign-up bonus — enough for 2-5 free nights right out of the gate.

My approach:

  1. Earn Hilton points from a credit card (groceries, gas, dining all count)
  2. Book award nights at pet-friendly properties
  3. Pay only the pet fee out of pocket

A $200/night room + $75 pet fee becomes just $75. Much easier to stomach.

Not sure which card? Take the quiz to find the best Hilton card for your travel style.

Hilton Elite Status & Pet Travel

Elite status makes traveling with a dog easier:

Benefit Why It Matters for Dog Owners
Room upgrades More space for your pup
Late checkout Extra time for morning walks
5th night free 20% off longer stays
F&B credit (Diamond) Offset pet fee costs

Gold status comes free with the Hilton Surpass card. Diamond status comes free with the Hilton Aspire card — or by spending $40k/year on the Surpass.

Learn more: Hilton Diamond Status: How to Get It and Why It’s Worth It

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I bring 2 dogs to Hilton?

Most Hilton properties allow up to 2 pets. The weight limit usually applies per pet (so two 50-lb dogs may be fine, but two 75-lb dogs might exceed the limit). Always confirm with the specific property.

Are there breed restrictions at Hilton?

Hilton doesn’t have corporate breed restrictions, but individual properties (especially in certain cities or states) may restrict certain breeds due to local laws or insurance requirements. Call ahead if you have a pit bull, Rottweiler, or other commonly restricted breed.

Can I leave my dog alone in the room?

Policies vary. Some properties require dogs to be crated if left alone. Others don’t allow pets to be left unattended at all. Ask at check-in to avoid problems.

What if my dog damages the room?

You’ll be charged for any damage. Most properties take a credit card on file. Be honest about damage — trying to hide it makes things worse.

Does Hilton provide pet amenities?

Some properties offer beds, bowls, or treats. It’s not guaranteed, so bring your own supplies. Canopy by Hilton is known for having treats at check-in.

The Bottom Line

Hilton is one of the most reliable hotel chains for dog owners. Every brand accepts pets, policies are fairly consistent, and their footprint means you’ll find a pet-friendly option almost anywhere.

The key is confirming details with each property before you book — weight limits and fees vary, and a quick phone call prevents surprises at check-in.

And if you’re paying for hotels anyway, consider earning Hilton points through a credit card. The pet fee is a lot easier to swallow when the room is free.

item.title: IHG Pet Policy Guide: Why Kimpton Is the Best Chain for Large Dogs
item.description:
If you’ve been following along, you know I’m obsessed with Hilton for dog travel. But here’s the thing: IHG has a secret weapon that even Hilton can’t match.

It’s called Kimpton.

Kimpton is hands-down the most dog-friendly hotel brand in existence. No weight limits. No breed restrictions. No pet fees. Ever. They’ll welcome your Great Dane the same way they’d welcome a Chihuahua.

But Kimpton is just one piece of the IHG puzzle. Let me break down the entire IHG portfolio so you know exactly where you can (and can’t) bring your dog.

The IHG Pet-Friendly Lineup

IHG has 20 hotel brands, but not all of them welcome dogs. Here’s what you need to know:

Tier 1: The Gold Standard

Kimpton Hotels ⭐ THE BEST

  • Weight limit: None (“If your pet fits through the door, we’ll welcome them in”)
  • Pet fee: $0
  • Breed restrictions: None
  • Number of pets: Unlimited
  • Pet types: Dogs, cats, birds, fish, even your pet lizard

Kimpton isn’t just pet-friendly — they’re pet-obsessed. Every property has a “Director of Pet Relations” (usually an adorable resident dog). They’ll greet your pet by name, provide beds and bowls, and even give you a list of nearby dog parks and pet-friendly restaurants.

The nightly wine hour? Your dog is invited.

Tier 2: Always Pet-Friendly (With Fees)

These brands welcome pets at ALL locations:

Staybridge Suites

  • Weight limit: 50 lbs (varies by property)
  • Pet fee: ~$75/week
  • Best for: Extended stays with a kitchen

Candlewood Suites

  • Weight limit: 80 lbs
  • Pet fee: $75 for 1-6 nights, $150 for 7+ nights
  • Best for: Budget-friendly extended stays

Both are extended-stay brands with full kitchens — perfect for longer trips when you want to cook for yourself (and your pup).

Tier 3: Often Pet-Friendly (Check First)

These brands have pet-friendly properties, but policies vary by location:

Hotel Indigo

  • Weight limit: 40-80 lbs (varies)
  • Pet fee: $50-$75 per stay
  • Vibe: Boutique, artsy, neighborhood-focused

InterContinental

  • Weight limit: Varies widely
  • Pet fee: Can be steep ($100-$250 in major cities)
  • Best for: Luxury stays when you can find a good deal

Crowne Plaza

  • Weight limit: Varies by property
  • Pet fee: Varies
  • Note: Not all locations are pet-friendly

Holiday Inn / Holiday Inn Express

  • Weight limit: Usually 40-50 lbs
  • Pet fee: $25-$75 per stay
  • Note: Very hit-or-miss — always call ahead

EVEN Hotels

  • Weight limit: Varies
  • Pet fee: Varies
  • Vibe: Wellness-focused, often in suburban areas

Tier 4: Usually NOT Pet-Friendly

  • Six Senses
  • Regent
  • Vignette Collection
  • HUALUXE

Why Kimpton Wins for Large Dogs

Let me be real: if you have a dog over 50 lbs, Kimpton is your only guaranteed option in the IHG family.

Here’s why this matters:

Brand 70-lb Dog Allowed?
Kimpton ✅ Yes, always
Candlewood Suites ✅ Yes (under 80 lbs)
Staybridge Suites ❌ No (50 lb limit)
Hotel Indigo ⚠️ Maybe (check property)
Holiday Inn ❌ Usually no

Ansel weighs 70 lbs. At Kimpton, nobody blinks. At most other IHG brands, we’d be turned away.

How to Earn IHG Points for Free Stays

Here’s where it gets good. You can stay at Kimpton for free using IHG One Rewards points.

The IHG Credit Cards

IHG One Rewards Premier Credit Card ($99/year)

  • 140,000 bonus points after $3,000 spend
  • Free night certificate every year (up to 40,000 points value)
  • 4th night free on award stays
  • Automatic Platinum Elite status

IHG One Rewards Traveler Credit Card ($0/year)

  • 80,000 bonus points after $2,000 spend
  • No annual fee
  • Silver Elite status

Point Values

IHG points are worth about 0.5-0.6 cents each. A typical Kimpton redemption runs 30,000-60,000 points per night, though prices vary by date and location.

Pro tip: The 4th night free perk on the Premier card is huge. Book 4 nights and you essentially get 25% off your points redemption.

Transfer Partners

You can also transfer points to IHG from:

  • Chase Ultimate Rewards (1:1)
  • Bilt Rewards (1:1)

But honestly? IHG points aren’t the best use of Chase points. I’d rather transfer to Hyatt. The IHG credit card bonuses are usually the better path.

Kimpton vs. Hilton: Which Is Better for Dogs?

I get this question a lot. Here’s my honest take:

Factor Kimpton Hilton
Pet fees $0 $0-$75 (varies)
Weight limits None None (most brands)
Number of properties ~70 7,000+
Loyalty program IHG One Rewards Hilton Honors
Point value ~0.5¢ ~0.5¢
Best for Boutique experience, guaranteed pet-friendly More locations, easier to find availability

My verdict: Kimpton is technically more dog-friendly, but Hilton’s massive footprint makes it more practical for everyday travel. I use both.

If there’s a Kimpton where I’m going? I book it. If not? Hilton it is.

Tips for Booking Pet-Friendly IHG Stays

  1. Always call the property directly — Even “dog-friendly” hotels can have restrictions that aren’t listed online.

  2. Book Kimpton for guaranteed acceptance — Don’t risk showing up with your 70-lb dog only to be told there’s a 50-lb limit.

  3. Use the IHG app filter — Search for “Pet Friendly” under amenities, but verify the specific policy.

  4. Stack promotions — IHG frequently runs double/triple point promotions. Combine with credit card bonuses for maximum value.

  5. Consider extended-stay brands — Candlewood and Staybridge have kitchens, which is clutch for longer trips with dogs (no restaurant hunting!).

The Bottom Line

If you’re traveling with a large dog and want zero stress about pet policies, Kimpton is unbeatable. No weight limits, no fees, no judgment.

The trade-off? There are only about 70 Kimpton properties, mostly in major cities. You won’t find one in every small town.

For broader coverage, pair your IHG strategy with Hilton. Between the two programs, you’ll have pet-friendly options almost anywhere.

My recommendation:

  • Get the IHG Premier card for Kimpton stays ($99/year, free night certificate pays for itself)
  • Get the Hilton Surpass or Aspire for everywhere else
  • Never pay pet fees again

Have you stayed at a Kimpton with your dog? I’d love to hear about your experience — leave a pawprint and tell me which property!

item.title: Kimpton Pet Policy 2025: No Fees, No Weight Limits, No Restrictions
item.description:
If you’ve traveled with a dog — especially a big one — you know the frustration of weight limits, breed restrictions, and pet fees that cost as much as another night’s stay.

Kimpton doesn’t do any of that.

Kimpton’s pet policy is simple: if your pet fits through the door, they’re welcome. No weight limit. No breed restrictions. No pet fee. Ever.

Here’s everything you need to know about staying at Kimpton with your dog.

Disclosure: This post contains affiliate links. If you apply for a card through my links, I may earn a commission at no extra cost to you. See my full disclosure for details.

Jump to:

  • The Policy
  • What Makes Kimpton Different
  • Pet Amenities
  • Where to Find Kimptons
  • How to Book Free
  • FAQs

Kimpton’s Pet Policy: The Details

Policy Kimpton
Pet fee $0 (free)
Weight limit None
Breed restrictions None
Number of pets No limit
Pet types Dogs, cats, birds, fish, and more

That’s not a typo. Kimpton has no weight limit. They’ve welcomed Great Danes, Saint Bernards, and everything in between. Their unofficial motto is “if they fit through the door, they’re welcome.”

What Makes Kimpton Different

Kimpton didn’t just add “pet-friendly” to their website and call it a day. They built their entire brand around welcoming pets.

No Fees, Period

Most “pet-friendly” hotels charge $50–$150 per stay. Kimpton charges nothing. Stay a week with your dog and you’re saving $100+ compared to other chains.

No Weight Limits

This is the big one. Most hotels cap pets at 50–75 lbs. If you have a German Shepherd, Lab, Golden Retriever, or any other large breed, you’ve probably been turned away before.

At Kimpton, your 100-lb dog is just as welcome as a 10-lb dog. No awkward conversations at check-in. No hoping they don’t notice your dog is “a little over” the limit.

No Breed Restrictions

Pit bulls, Rottweilers, Dobermans, German Shepherds — breeds that some hotels ban entirely are welcome at Kimpton. They judge dogs by behavior, not breed.

It’s Not Just Tolerance — It’s Celebration

Many Kimpton properties have a Director of Pet Relations — yes, that’s a dog with an official title. They host pet-friendly events, keep treats at the front desk, and genuinely love seeing dogs in the lobby.

The nightly wine hour? Your dog is invited.

Pet Amenities at Kimpton

Kimpton doesn’t just allow pets — they roll out the red carpet:

  • Pet beds and bowls available on request (often in the room already)
  • Treats at check-in at most properties
  • Pet-friendly mini bar items at some locations
  • Local pet recommendations — dog parks, pet stores, vet clinics
  • Dog-walking services at select properties
  • Pet-sitting referrals if you need a night out

Some Kimptons even have dog-friendly restaurant patios on property where your pup can join you for dinner.

Kimpton Locations

Kimpton operates 77+ hotels in the U.S. plus a few international locations. They’re a boutique brand, so you won’t find one in every small town — but they’re well-represented in major cities and popular destinations.

Cities with Multiple Kimptons:

  • San Francisco (where Kimpton started)
  • New York City
  • Los Angeles
  • Chicago
  • Washington D.C.
  • Seattle
  • Denver
  • Austin
  • Miami / South Florida
  • Portland
  • Boston

Notable Dog-Friendly Kimptons:

Kimpton Hotel Monaco (Denver, Salt Lake City, Portland, others) Downtown locations with easy access to parks and trails. Known for particularly welcoming staff.

Kimpton Brice Hotel (Savannah) Enclosed courtyard perfect for the wine hour with your pup. Walking distance to Forsyth Park.

Kimpton Rowan (Palm Springs) Desert getaway with multiple dog parks nearby and pet-friendly restaurant patios everywhere.

Kimpton Arras (Asheville) Gateway to Blue Ridge Mountains hiking. Asheville is one of the most dog-friendly cities in the country.

Kimpton Journeyman (Milwaukee) Dedicated pet-friendly floors. Great urban location.

How to Book Kimpton Free with Points

Kimpton is part of IHG One Rewards (InterContinental Hotels Group). You can book free stays using IHG points.

Earning IHG Points

Option 1: IHG Credit Cards

Card Annual Fee Sign-Up Bonus Best For
IHG One Rewards Traveler $0 80,000 points No-risk starting point
IHG One Rewards Premier $99 140,000 points Regular Kimpton stays

The Premier card also gives you:

  • 4th night free on award stays — book 4 nights, pay for 3 with points
  • Free night certificate every year (up to 40,000 points value)
  • Platinum Elite status — room upgrades when available

Option 2: Transfer from Chase Ultimate Rewards

Chase points transfer 1:1 to IHG. If you have a Chase Sapphire Preferred or Reserve, you can move points to IHG when you find a Kimpton you want to book.

How Many Points for a Kimpton Stay?

IHG uses dynamic pricing, so point costs vary. Typical Kimpton redemptions:

Demand Points per Night
Off-peak 25,000–40,000
Standard 40,000–60,000
Peak 70,000–100,000+

Pro tip: The 4th night free benefit on the IHG Premier card is huge for Kimpton stays. A 4-night trip that would cost 200,000 points becomes 150,000 — that’s 25% off.

For the full breakdown: How to Book Kimpton Hotels Free with Points

Kimpton vs. Other Pet-Friendly Hotels

Factor Kimpton Hilton Marriott
Pet fee $0 $50–$95 $75–$150
Weight limit None 50–75 lbs 25–75 lbs
Breed restrictions None None (usually) Varies
Number of properties 77+ 7,000+ 8,000+
Best for Large dogs, avoiding fees Most locations, points earning Widest footprint

The trade-off: Kimpton has the best pet policy, but the smallest footprint. You won’t find a Kimpton in every city. For those destinations, Hilton or Marriott are solid backups.

My approach: Book Kimpton whenever there’s one where I’m going. Use Hilton for everywhere else.

Frequently Asked Questions

Is Kimpton really free for pets?

Yes. No pet fee, no deposit, no hidden charges. This has been their policy since 1992 and they’ve never wavered.

What’s the actual weight limit?

There isn’t one. They’ve hosted Great Danes, Mastiffs, and Irish Wolfhounds. If your dog can walk through the door, they’re welcome.

Can I bring multiple pets?

Yes. Kimpton doesn’t limit the number of pets. Traveling with 3 dogs? Still welcome, still free.

What about cats, birds, or other pets?

Kimpton welcomes all pets — dogs, cats, birds, rabbits, fish, even monkeys (yes, really). They’re not dog-specific like some “pet-friendly” hotels.

Do I need to notify them in advance?

It’s courteous to mention you’re bringing a pet when booking, but it’s not required. You won’t be turned away for showing up with a dog.

Can my dog be alone in the room?

Kimpton allows pets to be left in the room as long as they’re comfortable and won’t disturb other guests. If your dog barks when alone, consider crating them or taking them with you.

Are there pet-friendly rooms vs. regular rooms?

No distinction. Every room at Kimpton is pet-friendly. You won’t be relegated to a ground-floor smoking room from 1987.

What if my dog damages something?

You’re responsible for any damage, same as any hotel. But Kimpton doesn’t require a pet deposit, which shows how confident they are in pet owners.

The Bottom Line

If you have a large dog, a “scary” breed, or you’re just tired of paying pet fees, Kimpton is the answer. No other major hotel chain comes close to their pet policy.

The only downside is their limited footprint — 77 hotels doesn’t compete with Hilton’s 7,000. But when there’s a Kimpton where you’re going, book it. Your dog will thank you.

item.title: Traveling with a Large Dog: Hotel Policies You Need to Know
item.description:
When you’re traveling with a small dog, finding dog-friendly hotels is pretty straightforward. But once your pup crosses that 50-pound threshold? Suddenly half your options disappear.

I travel with Ansel, my 70-pound German Shorthaired Pointer/Lab mix. He’s a lanky, well-behaved sweetheart—but on paper, he’s “too big” for a lot of hotels. If you’re in the same boat with your large dog, here’s everything I’ve learned about navigating hotel weight limits.

The Weight Limit Problem

Most hotel chains set their pet weight limits between 50-75 pounds. The logic seems to be liability and room size, but the limits often feel arbitrary. A calm 80-pound Lab is going to cause fewer issues than a hyper 30-pound terrier, but policies don’t account for temperament.

Here’s what you’ll typically see:

  • Under 50 lbs: Welcome almost everywhere
  • 50-75 lbs: Many options, but you’ll need to check policies
  • 75+ lbs: Options get limited fast

The good news? Several hotel chains have no weight limits at all, and others are more flexible than their official policies suggest.

Hotels with NO Weight Limits

These chains welcome dogs of any size—no awkward conversations at check-in required.

Kimpton Hotels

The gold standard for large dog travel. Their unofficial motto is “if they fit through the door, they’re welcome.” They’ve hosted everything from Great Danes to llamas. No pet fee, no weight limit, and many properties have a resident “Director of Pet Relations” (a very good dog). The nightly wine reception often welcomes pups too.

Best for: Travelers who want a boutique experience and don’t mind paying more per night.

Motel 6 / Studio 6

The most budget-friendly option for large dogs. No pet fee at Motel 6, and no weight or breed restrictions. Studio 6 (their extended stay brand) charges around $10/night but still has no size limit.

Best for: Road trippers who need affordable, no-questions-asked pet lodging.

La Quinta

La Quinta used to be the holy grail—no pet fee and no weight limit. Since Wyndham acquired them, policies vary more by location. Many still have no restrictions, but some now cap at 75 pounds with a $25/night fee. Always call ahead to confirm.

Best for: Frequent travelers who want consistency and don’t mind calling to verify.

Red Roof Inn

No weight limit, no breed restrictions, and no pet fee. They also provide designated dog walk areas with waste bags at each location. A solid budget option that genuinely welcomes large dogs.

Best for: Budget road trips where you want a pet-friendly guarantee.

Loews Hotels

All 24 Loews properties accept dogs of any size. The “Loews Loves Pets” program provides beds, bowls, treats, and even a room service menu for dogs. Fees vary by property but are typically reasonable for the upscale experience.

Best for: Special occasions when you want to treat yourself and your pup.

Sonesta (All Brands)

Royal Sonesta, Sonesta Hotels, Sonesta Select, Sonesta ES Suites, and Sonesta Simply Suites all allow pets with no breed or size limit. Standard fee is $75 per stay (or $150 for stays over 7 nights).

Best for: Extended stays and business travel with your dog.

Hotels with 75-80 lb Limits

If your dog is in the 50-80 pound range, these chains will likely work:

Chain Weight Limit Pet Fee Notes
Best Western 80 lbs per dog ~$30/night Policies vary by location
Drury Hotels 80 lbs combined $50/night Up to 2 pets
Candlewood Suites 80 lbs $75-150/stay IHG property
My Place Hotels 80 lbs $15-30/night Midwest-focused chain
Extended Stay America 36" x 36" Varies Measures by size, not weight!

Pro tip: Extended Stay America measures dogs by dimensions rather than weight. If your dog is under 36 inches tall and 36 inches long, you’re good—that covers most large breeds except giant breeds.

What About Hilton?

Since I focus a lot on Hilton for points travel, here’s the reality: most Hilton brands cap at 50-75 pounds, and it varies by property.

Hilton brands that tend to be more flexible:

  • Home2 Suites (75 lb limit)
  • Hilton Garden Inn (75 lb limit at most locations)
  • Homewood Suites (75 lb limit)
  • DoubleTree (varies widely—some have no limit)
  • Canopy by Hilton (very pet-friendly, 50-75 lbs)

Always call the specific property before booking. The website might say 50 pounds, but the front desk often has discretion—especially for well-behaved dogs.

If you’re earning Hilton points for dog travel, check out my Hilton credit card quiz to find the right card for your travel style.

Tips for When Your Dog Exceeds the Limit

Here’s what I’ve learned from traveling with a dog who’s technically “too big” for some policies:

1. Call the hotel directly

Don’t just book online and hope for the best. Call the front desk, explain your dog’s size and temperament, and ask if they can accommodate you. Many hotels will say yes even if the official policy says no—they care more about behavior than the number on the scale.

2. Be honest

Don’t lie about your dog’s weight. If you show up with an obviously-larger-than-stated dog, you risk being turned away. Honesty builds trust and often gets you further than trying to sneak by.

3. Mention good behavior

“He’s 70 pounds but very calm and well-trained” goes a long way. Hotels worry about noise complaints and damage—if you can reassure them your dog won’t cause issues, they’re more likely to flex on the weight limit.

4. Offer a larger deposit

If a hotel is hesitant, offering to put down a larger refundable deposit can ease their concerns. It shows you’re confident in your dog’s behavior.

5. Book pet-friendly room types

Some hotels have designated pet rooms that can accommodate larger dogs. Ask specifically about these when you call.

6. Use BringFido

BringFido is the best resource for finding genuinely pet-friendly hotels. They verify policies and can even help negotiate weight limit exceptions through their Canine Concierge service.

7. Use the Hotel Pet Policy Finder

Not sure about a specific chain’s policy? Use my Hotel Pet Policy Finder to quickly check weight limits and fees for any major hotel brand.

The Reality Check

Hotels rarely actually weigh dogs. Most front desk staff will eyeball your pup and decide if they’re comfortable. A well-groomed, calm dog on a leash makes a much better impression than a dog that’s pulling and barking—regardless of size.

That said, don’t abuse this. If a hotel says 50 pounds and you show up with a 120-pound Mastiff, you’re putting the staff in an awkward position and potentially ruining it for other large-dog travelers.

My Go-To Strategy

For road trips with Ansel, here’s my approach:

  1. First choice: La Quinta or Red Roof Inn (no restrictions, budget-friendly)
  2. If I want something nicer: Kimpton or Loews (splurge-worthy, genuinely welcoming)
  3. If using Hilton points: Home2 Suites or Homewood Suites (call ahead to confirm)
  4. Always: Call the specific property before booking to confirm they’ll welcome my 70-pound guy

The Bottom Line

Traveling with a large dog takes more planning, but it’s absolutely doable. The key is knowing which chains are genuinely welcoming versus which ones just tolerate pets. Stick with the no-weight-limit chains for stress-free bookings, and always call ahead when you’re unsure.

Your big dog deserves adventures too. Don’t let arbitrary weight limits keep you home.

item.title: Why Hilton Is the Best Hotel Chain for Dog Travelers
item.description:
When I started traveling with Ansel, my 70-pound GSP/Lab mix, I quickly learned that not all hotel chains are created equal. Some properties say they’re “pet-friendly” but hit you with breed restrictions, weight limits, or fees that make you feel like your dog isn’t actually welcome.

Hilton is different. Here’s why it’s become my go-to for dog travel.

Every Hilton Brand Welcomes Dogs

This is the big one. Whether you’re staying at a Hampton Inn on a road trip or splurging on a Waldorf Astoria for a special occasion, every Hilton brand in the U.S. accepts pets.

That consistency matters when you’re planning trips with a dog. No more calling ahead to individual properties hoping they’ll say yes. No more getting turned away at check-in because someone didn’t update the website.

The brands include:

  • Hampton Inn & Suites
  • Hilton Garden Inn
  • Home2 Suites
  • Homewood Suites
  • DoubleTree
  • Embassy Suites
  • Hilton Hotels & Resorts
  • Canopy by Hilton
  • Curio Collection
  • Tapestry Collection
  • Conrad Hotels
  • Waldorf Astoria

One caveat: Weight limits vary by property, typically ranging from 50-75 lbs. If you have a larger dog, always call ahead to confirm. Check out my guide to traveling with large dogs for more tips.

Points Are Easy to Earn

Hilton points are some of the easiest hotel points to stack through everyday spending. With the right credit card, you can earn points on:

  • Groceries (including all that dog food)
  • Gas stations (road trip fuel-ups)
  • Restaurants (dog-friendly patios count!)
  • Vet bills and pet supplies
  • Everything else

I’ve booked multiple free nights at pet-friendly Hiltons without setting foot in a hotel — just from everyday spending on my Hilton credit card.

Not sure which card is right for you? Take my quick quiz to find your perfect match.

Diamond Status Makes Dog Travel Easier

Hilton’s top-tier status, Diamond, comes with perks that are especially valuable when you’re traveling with a dog:

Room upgrades — More space means more room for your pup to spread out. I’ve been upgraded to suites multiple times, and the extra square footage makes a huge difference with a 70-pound dog.

Late checkout — Morning potty breaks, packing up dog gear, loading the car… it all takes longer with a pet. Late checkout (often until 2pm) gives you breathing room.

Daily food & beverage credit — Pet fees add up. Having your meals partially covered helps offset those costs.

Executive lounge access — A quiet spot to grab coffee or a snack, away from the chaos of the main lobby.

The best part? You don’t have to stay 60 nights a year to get Diamond. The Hilton Aspire card gives you automatic Diamond status just for having the card.

Pet Fees Are Reasonable

Hilton pet fees typically range from $50-$95 per stay, depending on the brand and location. That’s middle-of-the-road for the industry — not the cheapest, but far from the worst offenders.

When you’re booking on points, the pet fee is often your only out-of-pocket cost. I’ll happily pay $75 for a “free” hotel stay at a property I know will welcome my dog without hassle.

My Hilton Dog Travel Stack

Here’s the setup I use for earning and booking dog-friendly Hilton stays:

  1. Hilton Aspire Card — Automatic Diamond status, annual free night certificate, $400 resort credit
  2. Hilton Points — Earned from everyday spending, used for free nights
  3. 5th Night Free — Book 4 nights on points, get the 5th free (20% savings!)
  4. BringFido — For double-checking pet policies and weight limits at specific properties

This combo has gotten me free stays at dog-friendly Embassy Suites, Hilton Garden Inns, and more — with Ansel welcome at every single one.

Ready to Start?
